title: Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Open Borders
summary: Directs federal agencies to review immigration policies to reduce federal funds supporting illegal immigration.
full_text: Directs federal agencies to review immigration policies to reduce federal funds supporting illegal immigration.
plain_language_summary:
Reviewing Immigration Policies to Reduce Illegal Immigration Funding

Overview: Executive Order 14113 directs federal agencies to review their immigration-related policies, guidance, and practices. The goal is to identify and eliminate any federal funding that directly or indirectly supports illegal immigration.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions should assess whether any of their federal funding could be at risk due to direct or indirect support of illegal immigration.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Federal Grants: Review federal grants to ensure compliance with immigration-related eligibility requirements.

Financial Aid: Confirm student aid is not inadvertently supporting students engaged in illegal immigration.

Research Funding: Evaluate research funding sources and projects for any immigration-related risks.

Affected Departments:

Government Affairs, Financial Aid Office, Research Administration, Legal Counsel

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes, institutions should proactively review policies and funding for potential immigration compliance gaps.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review the institution's policies related to verifying immigration status.
  • Identify federal funding streams with immigration-related eligibility criteria.
  • Meet with affected departments to coordinate an immigration compliance review.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Audit federal grants, financial aid, and research funding for immigration risks.
  • Develop an action plan to remediate any identified compliance gaps.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Monitor evolving federal immigration policies for impact on the institution.
  • Provide immigration compliance training to relevant personnel.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Staff time to conduct immigration compliance review and remediation.

Budget: Potential need for outside immigration counsel. Possible reduction in federal aid/funding.

Technology: Systems to track/verify immigration status may need enhancement.

External Expertise: Immigration legal counsel to assist with compliance review.
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

The White House directs agencies to review immigration policies to reduce federal funding that may be supporting illegal immigration.
comprehensive_analysis:
Assessing Federal Funding Streams for Immigration Compliance Risks

Overview: Executive Order 14113, titled 'Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Open Borders', initiates a broad federal review of immigration-related policies, guidance, procedures and practices. The stated intention is to identify and eliminate any sources of federal funding that are directly or indirectly supporting illegal immigration. For higher education institutions, this means assessing whether any federal aid, grants, or research dollars could be at risk due to insufficient immigration compliance controls.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions need to proactively audit their federal funding streams and related compliance practices to surface and address any potential issues regarding improper support of illegal immigration. Both direct funding and pass-through funding are in scope.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

U.S. immigration enforcement has been contentious across recent administrations. This EO escalates matters by tying immigration concerns to federal funding, which is a critical revenue stream for many colleges and universities.

Legal Framework:

Various statutes restrict federal public benefits to U.S. citizens or certain legal immigrants (e.g. 8 USC §§1611, 1621). But application to higher education has had limited enforcement to date.

Higher Education Context:

Higher education is under mounting scrutiny and financial pressure on multiple fronts. Losing access to federal funding over immigration issues would be devastating for many institutions.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Federal Student Aid: Review eligibility criteria, verification procedures, and disbursement practices for federal financial aid to ensure only legal recipients.

Research Grants: Assess research personnel, partnerships, and funding sources for immigration-related risks and proper oversight.

Other Grants/Contracts: Systematically audit all other federal funding agreements to identify any with immigration status requirements for participation.

Enrollment Management: Admissions, registration and student support processes should be evaluated for sufficient immigration compliance and documentation.

Sponsored Programs: Build immigration compliance reviews into processes for pursuing federal funding opportunities and managing awarded projects.

Affected Departments:

Financial Aid Office, Research Administration, Sponsored Programs Office, Enrollment Management, Government Affairs, Legal Counsel, Administration & Finance

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Leverage existing Form I-9 and E-Verify employment eligibility verification processes as well as SEVIS tracking for international students. Ensure consistent processes and documentation of legal immigration status across all areas related to federal funding eligibility.

Technical Analysis:

Federal funding agreements likely to require certifications of institutional immigration compliance, so underlying procedures and systems must be sufficiently sophisticated and deterministic to support such certifications.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

An immigration compliance review regarding federal funds will necessarily touch many areas and require extensive cross-departmental cooperation to be effective. Upfront coordination is critical.

Risk Analysis:

Significant compliance risk from lack of consistent, verifiable immigration procedures for federal fund recipients. But overcorrecting also poses risks (e.g. national origin discrimination). Expert guidance is essential.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions with tighter oversight of immigration matters may have an advantage in competing for federal funding. Those reliant on federal aid for undocumented/DACA students are at serious risk.

Long-term Vision:

Immigration will remain a key issue for higher ed federal policy. Developing maturity and consistency in compliance approaches will be critical for securing an institution's funding future.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher education associations will likely coordinate efforts to help shape reasonable implementation parameters. Individual institutions can engage as appropriate for their circumstances.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes, this EO demands a thorough institutional review of federal funding exposure and proactive remediation of any deficiencies - both to safeguard current funding and preserve future opportunities.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Brief senior leadership on the EO and develop an action plan for an immigration compliance review.
  • Identify all federal funding streams and the associated immigration-related requirements.
  • Pinpoint high-risk areas such as financial aid, sponsored research, and admissions for priority attention.
  • Engage experienced immigration counsel to support the compliance assessment and remediation planning.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Complete cross-functional immigration compliance audit of federal funding lifecycles - from application through closeout.
  • Identify and implement corrective actions for any compliance gaps, with particular urgency for areas with current funding.
  • Update policies, procedures, training, and documentation to ensure ongoing immigration compliance.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Make immigration compliance a core competency with clear roles and governance processes.
  • Monitor developments in federal immigration enforcement that could impact eligibility for future funding.
  • Consider strategic/legal input to federal implementation to mitigate overreach.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Significant staff/faculty time needed for compliance review and remediation across multiple departments. Central compliance lead role likely required.

Budget: Third-party immigration counsel will add expense. Potential for reduced federal aid revenue and increased operational costs for enhanced compliance.

Technology: May need system enhancements for consolidated immigration status tracking across the organization and reporting to federal funders.

External Expertise: External immigration compliance experts will be needed to effectively assess risks and design compliant procedures and controls.

title: Expanding Access to In Vitro Fertilization
summary: Directs the Department of Health and Human Services to support access to IVF and other reproductive health services.
full_text: Directs the Department of Health and Human Services to support access to IVF and other reproductive health services.
plain_language_summary:
Expanding IVF and Reproductive Health Access

Overview: This executive order directs HHS to support access to in vitro fertilization (IVF) and other reproductive health services. The primary goal is expanding availability of assisted reproductive technologies.

Bottom Line: Limited immediate impact on higher ed, but may affect employee health benefits long-term.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Employee Health Benefits: Potential long-term changes to coverage of IVF and reproductive services

Student Health Services: Possible expansion of referrals for reproductive health services

Medical Research: May create opportunities related to assisted reproduction

Affected Departments:

Human Resources, Benefits Administration, Student Health Services

Action Plan:

Action Required: No. This order requires no immediate institutional response.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review order and assess potential long-term impacts

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor HHS guidance for changes affecting employee or student health coverage

Long-term Considerations:

  • Consider adapting health plans if regulations change substantially

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: No additional personnel needed

Budget: No immediate budget impact

Technology: No new technology required

External Expertise: Benefits consultant guidance on regulatory changes
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Executive order supports expanded access to in vitro fertilization and reproductive health services. Minimal direct impact on higher education institutions.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order on Expanding Access to In Vitro Fertilization and Reproductive Health Services

Overview: This executive order directs the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to take actions supporting access to in vitro fertilization (IVF) and other reproductive health services. It aims to expand availability and affordability of assisted reproductive technologies, though specific initiatives are not yet defined.

Bottom Line: Limited immediate regulatory impact on higher education institutions, but potential long-term effects on employee health benefits and student services.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

Builds on previous efforts to require insurance coverage for infertility treatments and ensure access to reproductive health services. Follows recent state actions restricting or protecting abortion.

Legal Framework:

Relies on HHS authority to regulate group health plans and essential health benefits. Specific statutory basis and preemption of state law to be determined based on details.

Higher Education Context:

Many large employers have expanded IVF and fertility benefits to attract talent and promote DEI. Higher ed has lagged on fully-inclusive coverage.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Employee Health Benefits: Potential future requirement to cover IVF and expanded reproductive services, which could increase costs. Institutions may need to re-assess health plan design.

Student Health Services: Possible expansion of gynecological and reproductive health services for students, including referrals to IVF providers. May require adapting health center staffing and resources.

Medical Schools and Research: Could create research opportunities and funding in assisted reproduction. Relevant for universities with reproductive endocrinology or embryology programs.

Legal and Compliance: Must monitor regulations and adapt policies for any new coverage mandates or reporting. Review implications for self-insured health plans.

Diversity, Equity and Inclusion: Removes barriers to family building, especially for LGBTQ+ individuals. Demonstrates commitment to reproductive rights and inclusive benefits.

Important Dates:

  • 2024 Q4: Anticipated initial HHS proposals based on order
  • 2025 plan year: Potential effective date of any new coverage mandates

Affected Departments:

Human Resources, Benefits Administration, Finance and Budget, Student Health Services, Research Administration, Legal Affairs, Government Relations

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Key areas to watch: 1) Essential health benefits requirements for IVF and infertility treatment, 2) Annual and lifetime coverage limits, 3) Definition of infertility and covered treatments, 4) Required pre-authorizations and patient cost-sharing, 5) Potential exemptions for religious organizations

Technical Analysis:

IVF is an advanced series of procedures that require specialized medical expertise. Coverage mandates could strain provider networks and clinical capacity. HHS may need to invest in training programs and incentives for clinicians. Telemedicine and employer Centers of Excellence can enhance access.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Expands reproductive health access across institution. Benefits design affects recruitment, retention and DEI goals. Student health must meet gynecological service expectations. Can inspire academic initiatives in public health, health policy, bioethics, and women's studies in addition to medicine.

Risk Analysis:

Compliance risks from misinterpreting new coverage requirements or disputes over medical necessity. Reputational risk from being unsupportive of reproductive rights amid likely political scrutiny. Financial exposure from unexpected utilization and cost increases, absent plan limits. Potential adverse selection in student health plan enrollment.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions that proactively expand IVF benefits and showcase inclusive family-building support can differentiate themselves in faculty and staff recruitment. May attract students who value comprehensive reproductive care. Avoiding or delaying enhancements risks perception as antiquated and talent flight to employers with better benefits.

Long-term Vision:

Fits broader trend of higher ed institutions as agents of health equity and progressive social values. Parity in access to family building will be an emergent expectation and focal point in DEI strategies. Opportunity to champion reproductive autonomy can inspire public service mission.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher ed coalitions may provide input to HHS on IVF coverage parameters, provider access standards, and special considerations for university health plans. Can emphasize need for funding support and point out interactions with student health policies. Consultation with institutions that have innovated in this area can shape realistic rulemaking.

Action Plan:

Action Required: No. Directs HHS, not higher ed institutions. However, important to monitor developments, as changes to health plan requirements are likely.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review existing employee and student health coverage for IVF and reproductive health
  • Assess competitiveness of current infertility benefits and identify gaps
  • Open dialogue with campus community about potential enhancements
  • Assign HR/benefits lead to monitor HHS actions and brief leadership

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Model scenarios of expanded IVF coverage on health plan costs
  • Collaborate with benefits consultants on proactive plan design changes
  • Develop communications strategy to frame any benefits enhancements

Long-term Considerations:

  • Adapt health plans and student services if significant regulatory changes
  • Review implications for self-insured plans and stop-loss coverage
  • Consider opportunities to lead in research and education on assisted reproduction

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Possible additional clinical staff for campus health services. Plan administration and communications. Government affairs to monitor policy.

Budget: Expanded IVF benefits likely to increase overall health plan costs 3-5% based on current utilization in other plans. Projections vary by coverage level.

Technology: May be need for new insurance claims coding and pre-authorization platforms

External Expertise: Consulting support for benefits design, actuarial modeling, legal/regulatory interpretation, and employee communications

title: Ensuring Accountability for All Agencies
summary: Directs federal agencies to improve transparency and accountability in their operations and decision-making.
full_text: Directs federal agencies to improve transparency and accountability in their operations and decision-making.
plain_language_summary:
Improving Federal Agency Transparency and Accountability

Overview: This executive order directs all federal agencies to enhance transparency and accountability in their operations and decision-making processes. The primary goal is to bolster public trust in government.

Bottom Line: While important for good governance, this order has limited direct impact on higher education institutions.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Reporting requirements: Universities may need to provide additional information for certain federal grants and contracts.

Auditing: Potential for more stringent audits of how federal funds are utilized.

Public perception: Improved public perception of government partners may modestly benefit universities.

Affected Departments:

Sponsored Programs Office, Government Affairs, Public Relations

Action Plan:

Action Required: No. Stay informed but no immediate action required given minimal impacts.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review order and inform leadership
  • Assess potential grant/contract impacts

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor implementation of transparency requirements

Long-term Considerations:

  • Adapt reporting as needed

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: No additional personnel needed

Budget: No significant budget impact

Technology: Leverage existing grant management systems

External Expertise: None required
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Executive order aims to improve transparency and accountability across federal agencies. Minimal direct impact on universities expected.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order on Enhancing Transparency and Accountability in Federal Agencies

Overview: This executive order mandates all federal agencies to improve operational transparency and decision-making accountability to cultivate greater public trust. While an important policy shift, it is expected to have minimal direct impacts on colleges and universities.

Bottom Line: University leadership should be aware of this order but it requires no immediate action. Indirect impacts are modest.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This order continues a trend of multiple administrations pursuing improved government accountability, often in response to concerns about mismanagement and eroding public trust. However, past orders have tended to focus more on internal agency operations than external partners.

Legal Framework:

The order operates within existing statutory authority for executive branch oversight of federal agencies. It does not directly amend any regulations governing higher education.

Higher Education Context:

Universities have faced increasing scrutiny about their use of public funds, at both the state and federal level. This order may contribute to that trend but is unlikely to substantially alter the overall landscape.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Federal grants and contracts: Some additional reporting requirements may be imposed to enhance transparency in how federal funds are utilized by universities. However, major changes are unlikely.

Audits: Federal audits of university grants and contracts could moderately increase in frequency or depth to support the accountability goals of this order. Institutions with sound financial management practices are well-positioned to respond.

Public and government relations: Universities may benefit from a modest boost in public perception due to this action increasing trust in government partners. It may also slightly strengthen universities' government affairs efforts.

Research: Federally-funded research projects may be asked to accommodate new transparency measures, but overall impacts on university research will likely be minimal.

Long-term effects: If this order substantively improves public trust in federal agencies over time, it could help create a more positive environment for university partnerships. But major long-term impacts are not anticipated.

Affected Departments:

Sponsored Programs Office, Government Affairs, Public Relations, Research Administration, Financial Services

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

The order does not introduce any new statutory compliance requirements for universities. However, institutions should be prepared for potentially heightened disclosure and reporting expectations from funding agencies.

Technical Analysis:

While technical details are limited since the order focuses on broad goals, universities should anticipate that agencies will look to collect more quantitative data to enable transparency. They may need to adjust IT systems.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

This order touches multiple university functions including sponsored projects administration, government affairs, public relations, research administration, and financial management. Cross-functional coordination will help surface any issues.

Risk Analysis:

The primary risk is that enhanced transparency and accountability expectations could expose vulnerabilities in university grants/contracts compliance. Proactively assessing and addressing any weaknesses mitigates this risk.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

All universities that receive federal funding will be similarly affected, so this order does not create clear competitive advantages or disadvantages. However, institutions with stronger compliance may be better positioned.

Long-term Vision:

If successful in improving public trust, this order could help sustain federal support for higher education over the long run. Universities should consider how greater transparency might be leveraged in making the case for their societal value.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities, individually or through associations, should seek opportunities to provide input to agencies on how transparency measures can be effectively implemented without being overly burdensome.

Action Plan:

Action Required: No immediate action is required. The limited impacts on universities do not necessitate a direct response. However, university stakeholders should monitor implementation in case new requirements emerge.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Analyze the order and brief senior leadership on potential implications
  • Assess the current state of grant and contract compliance monitoring
  • Identify any high-risk areas that could be subject to enhanced scrutiny
  • Open lines of communication with campus stakeholders about this development

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor federal agencies for new grant/contract transparency requirements
  • Review disclosure and reporting practices to identify any gaps
  • Consider proactive steps to enhance transparency before new mandates

Long-term Considerations:

  • Stay attuned to any shifts in public perception driven by this order
  • Adapt university reporting and publicity practices if warranted
  • Look for opportunities to provide constructive feedback to agencies

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Existing personnel in affected departments can likely accommodate any incremental workload, but this should be monitored.

Budget: Limited budget impact expected unless agencies impose onerous new reporting mandates necessitating additional compliance staff.

Technology: Existing grant management and financial systems can likely be adapted for new requirements, but some enhancements may be needed.

External Expertise: Engaging external consultants is not anticipated unless highly specialized technical challenges emerge.

title: Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence
summary: Establishes new standards for AI safety and security while protecting Americans' privacy, advancing equity, and protecting workers' rights.
full_text: Establishes new standards for AI safety and security while protecting Americans' privacy, advancing equity, and protecting workers' rights.
plain_language_summary:
Executive Order on Responsible AI Development and Use

Overview: This order aims to ensure AI technologies are developed and used in a safe, secure, and trustworthy manner. It establishes new standards around AI safety, security, privacy, equity, and worker protections.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions involved in AI research and development will need to review practices for alignment with these new standards.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research: New safety and security requirements may affect AI research projects and funding.

Technology Transfer: Commercialization of AI technologies developed at universities will need to meet new standards.

Data Governance: Increased focus on privacy may require changes to data collection and use policies.

Important Dates:

  • TBD: Specific deadlines for agencies to develop plans and guidance

Affected Departments:

Research Administration, Technology Transfer Office, IT/Data Governance, Legal Affairs

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - Universities should review the order and assess implications for their AI programs and policies.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Designate point person to lead institutional response
  • Inform key stakeholders of the order
  • Schedule meeting to discuss initial assessment

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Conduct detailed analysis of institutional AI activities
  • Identify areas requiring policy or practice changes

Long-term Considerations:

  • Proactively shape internal AI governance framework
  • Engage with policymakers on evolving AI standards

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: May require additional compliance and policy staff

Budget: Potential increased compliance and legal costs

Technology: Enhanced security and data protection infrastructure

External Expertise: Engage outside experts to assess technical standards
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

President Biden issued an executive order establishing new standards for AI safety, security, privacy protection, equity, and worker rights that may impact technology development and use at universities.
comprehensive_analysis:
Establishing a Framework for Responsible AI Development and Use

Overview: This executive order seeks to proactively address the risks and societal implications of artificial intelligence as the technologies rapidly advance. It lays out a whole-of-government approach to ensure AI is developed and used in a safe, secure and trustworthy manner, with a focus on protecting privacy, promoting equity, and safeguarding workers.

Bottom Line: Universities are at the forefront of AI research and development. This order establishes new expectations and standards that institutions will need to carefully examine and integrate into their research, technology transfer, and data governance activities.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This order builds on prior U.S. AI initiatives like the National AI R&D Strategic Plan and recommendations from the National Security Commission on AI. It elevates AI to a top-level national priority.

Legal Framework:

Specific legal authorities and enforcement mechanisms are not yet clear. The order directs agencies to consider regulatory actions under existing laws. Universities will need to watch for new compliance requirements.

Higher Education Context:

The U.S. higher education sector is a global leader in AI research. This order seeks to maintain that leadership position while ensuring academic AI development aligns with societal values and protections.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Administration: New AI safety and security requirements may add compliance obligations for research projects and affect federal funding eligibility. Grants and contracts may face increased scrutiny.

Technology Transfer and Commercialization: AI technologies developed at universities will need to meet new standards before being licensed or spun off into startups. This could slow commercialization timelines.

Data Governance and Privacy: As a major source of the data used to train AI, universities will face pressure to strengthen privacy protections and ethical data practices. Data sharing with companies may be restricted.

AI Ethics and Policy: Universities will be expected to contribute to multistakeholder efforts to develop AI governance frameworks. There may be opportunities to shape policy through academic expertise.

Workforce and Education: An emphasis on protecting workers from AI-driven displacement may spur demand for AI education and reskilling programs. Universities should prepare to translate AI research into educational offerings.

Important Dates:

  • 90 days: Agencies submit plans to implement the order
  • 180 days: NIST to develop AI risk management framework
  • 1 year: Agencies report on AI use and impacts
  • Ongoing: Public engagement on AI policy development

Affected Departments:

President/Provost, Research Administration, Technology Transfer Office, IT and Data Governance, Legal Affairs, Ethics and Compliance, Government Affairs, Workforce Development

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Universities will need to map the evolving AI standards to institutional policies and procedures. This includes research integrity, human subjects protection, data management, export controls, intellectual property, and socially responsible licensing.

Technical Analysis:

The order emphasizes privacy-preserving AI techniques like federated learning and encrypted computation. Universities will need to build expertise in privacy-enhancing technologies. Technical security standards for AI will require investment.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

While research and technology transfer are most directly impacted, this order has implications university-wide. From data governance to workforce education to public engagement, a coordinated approach will be essential.

Risk Analysis:

Key risks include: Compliance gaps in existing practices, loss of funding for non-conforming research, liability from AI deployments, reputational damage from irresponsible AI, inability to attract top AI talent.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Universities that proactively align with these AI principles may have an advantage in federal funding, industry partnerships, and faculty and student recruitment. However, some researchers may feel constrained by new oversight.

Long-term Vision:

This order accelerates the integration of social responsibility into the AI innovation ecosystem. Universities are positioned to lead in developing the next generation of AI talent and shaping the future of trustworthy AI.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities should actively engage as the AI standards and governance frameworks are developed. There are opportunities to translate academic expertise into policy influence and shape the implementation of the order.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - The wide-reaching nature of this order necessitates a coordinated institutional response. Universities must thoroughly assess their AI activities, identify risk areas, and proactively develop governance strategies.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Brief senior leadership on the order and its implications

Executive Order on Improving Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery

Overview: President Biden issued an executive order directing federal agencies to make government services more transparent, equitable, and responsive to public needs. The order requires agencies to modernize programs, reduce administrative burdens, and pilot new online tools and technologies that can provide a simple, seamless, and secure customer experience.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This continues efforts from the Obama administration to improve citizen-facing government services, with a renewed emphasis on leveraging technology. It builds on recent CX initiatives like the 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act.

Legal Framework:

The order relies on existing statutory authority and mostly sets high-level strategic direction. Specific legal implications will depend on individual agency implementing actions.

Higher Education Context:

Colleges have also been working to improve student-centric services and user-friendly digital tools. This aligns with broader trends toward consumerization of higher education.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Financial Aid and Student Loans: Students may see more streamlined FAFSA processes, clearer communication, and improved online interfaces from the Department of Education.

Research Grant Administration: Faculty and staff may experience more user-friendly systems and less red tape when applying for and managing federal research grants from agencies like NSF, NIH, DoD, DOE, etc.

University Hospitals and Clinics: Medical centers may see modernized processes from CMS and VA related to reimbursement, reporting, and coordination of care.

Immigration and Study Abroad: International student services may see improved visa processes and communication from DHS, State Dept, and USCIS.

University Technology Transfer: Tech transfer offices may experience easier interactions with USPTO and Dept of Commerce.

Affected Departments:

Financial Aid Office, Bursar/Student Accounts, Registrar, Research Administration, Sponsored Projects Accounting, Technology Transfer Office, University Hospital Leadership, Government/Community Relations

Compliance Requirements:

N/A - Compliance impact minimal unless tied to specific federal funding streams.

Unclear how quickly legacy agency IT systems can implement modern CX tools. Interoperability with university systems will be important.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Implementation will span financial aid, registrar, billing, research admin, international programs, and government affairs. Requires cross-campus coordination.

Risk Analysis:

Low risk. Main issue would be investing in changes to university processes/systems that don't end up aligning with federal efforts.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Minimal - Most impacts will apply sector-wide. But universities with more seamless federal interactions could gain in student/faculty experience.

Long-term Vision:

Sets federal agencies on a path to provide more customer-centric, equitable, digitally-enabled public services. A more user-friendly relationship with key agencies like ED and research sponsors would benefit higher education in the long run.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities can comment on agency proposals, participate in user testing where offered, and advocate for tools/standards that enable integration with campus systems.

Action Plan:

The White House issued an order directing federal agencies to develop strategies for measuring, disclosing, and mitigating climate-related financial risks.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order on Climate-Related Financial Risk

Overview: Executive Order 14030 directs federal agencies to develop comprehensive strategies to measure, disclose, and mitigate climate-related financial risk to government programs, assets, and liabilities. The policy aims to protect government finances and build resilience against the intensifying impacts of climate change.

Bottom Line: Higher education institutions should carefully evaluate how climate change risks may materially impact their finances, investments, physical infrastructure, and access to federal funding in the coming years. Proactive planning will be critical.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This order builds on recent policies emphasizing climate risk as a core aspect of fiscal and economic policy, including the Paris Agreement. It's part of a broader push to orient government and the economy to address climate change.

Legal Framework:

The order derives broad authority from the president's Article II constitutional powers. Its directives will be implemented through various agency-specific statutory authorities related to procurement, lending, and financial regulation.

Higher Education Context:

Higher ed is increasingly focused on climate change but institutions vary widely in their risk exposure and preparedness. Some schools are leaders while others lack resources to adapt. This order could exacerbate disparities.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Financial management and accounting: Universities may need to thoroughly assess climate risks to their balance sheets and make disclosures to stakeholders. This could affect credit ratings, borrowing costs, and insurance.

Federal research funding: Agencies providing research grants/contracts may increasingly consider an institution's climate risk exposure and management. Universities heavily reliant on federal funding are especially vulnerable.

Campus infrastructure and facilities: Schools will likely need to account for climate risks like sea level rise, flooding, and extreme weather in campus planning, construction, and resilience efforts. This has major budget implications.

Endowment and investment management: College endowments may need to evaluate the climate risk exposure of their investment portfolios. This could lead to shifts in investment strategies toward more sustainable assets.

Student enrollment and recruitment: Students increasingly consider a school's sustainability and climate resilience when deciding where to attend. Lack of climate planning could make some institutions less competitive.

Affected Departments:

Finance and Administration, Facilities Management, Sponsored Research Office, Endowment and Investment Office, Procurement and Contracting

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

OMB and Treasury will provide detailed guidance on agency implementation, including new climate disclosure and mitigation requirements likely to impact higher ed institutions receiving federal funding.

Technical Analysis:

Modeling climate risks requires complex data analysis, scenario development, and financial projections. Schools will need specialized tools and talent to meet federal requirements.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Climate risk planning will impact everything from research administration and facilities to enrollment strategy and investment priorities. Sustained coordination is essential.

Risk Analysis:

Insufficient climate risk preparation could jeopardize access to federal funding, increase borrowing costs, reduce liquidity, and damage institutional reputations with students and the public.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Proactive climate risk management could become a major differentiator as students, faculty, and funding agencies make decisions based on climate factors. Under-resourced schools are at a disadvantage.

Long-term Vision:

The order accelerates an existing trend of linking climate change to core management functions like finance and strategy. Business as usual is no longer viable - climate risk must be a central planning consideration.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher ed associations should engage OMB, Treasury, and other agencies to ensure implementation accounts for institutional capacities and constraints. Schools can help shape evolving standards.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Not immediately but institutions would be wise to begin preparing. The order's broad scope and systemic focus suggests federal climate risk requirements will become increasingly common and stringent.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Assign a senior administrator to track the order's implementation across agencies
  • Brief the president, cabinet, and trustees on the order's expansive implications
  • Establish a climate risk task force with cross-functional representation
  • Conduct a preliminary assessment of potential climate risk exposures

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Evaluate current practices for assessing and disclosing climate risks
  • Identify federal revenue streams most vulnerable to climate risk considerations
  • Assess the climate resilience of existing infrastructure and facilities
  • Review investment holdings for major climate risk exposure

Long-term Considerations:

  • Develop a comprehensive climate risk management governance structure
  • Integrate climate risk assessment into core strategic and financial planning
  • Invest in personnel and tools to systematically monitor and disclose climate risks
  • Make climate resilience a focus of capital planning and infrastructure projects

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Institutions will need dedicated senior staff and cross-functional teams to lead climate risk assessment and mitigation

Budget: Significant resources required for new oversight personnel, analytic tools, consultants, and infrastructure resilience

Technology: Sophisticated climate risk modeling and disclosure software will be needed to efficiently assess and report risks

External Expertise: Most schools lack internal climate risk talent and will need to hire specialized consultants and auditors

comprehensive_analysis:
Re-establishment of White House Faith-Based Partnerships Office: Implications and Opportunities for Higher Education

Overview: President Biden's Executive Order 14018 re-establishes the White House Office of Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships, which was first formed under the George W. Bush administration and continued in modified form under Presidents Obama and Trump. The office aims to strengthen and coordinate the work of faith-based and community organizations in addressing major economic and social challenges, with a focus on poverty alleviation. While the executive order does not create any new funding streams or programs directly impacting higher education at this stage, it signals an intent to elevate public-private partnerships in the federal policy agenda. This may create opportunities for colleges and universities to align their community engagement, research, and economic development initiatives with emerging priorities from the office.

Bottom Line: The re-establishment of the White House faith-based partnerships office does not require immediate action from higher education administrators but warrants ongoing monitoring, as it could introduce new opportunities or expectations for institutions to collaborate with faith-based and community organizations in support of federal policy objectives, particularly in the economic development domain.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

The White House Office of Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships, originally established as the White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives under President George W. Bush, has evolved over the past two decades to serve as a liaison between the federal government and faith-based and community organizations. Under President Obama, the office was renamed and given a broader poverty reduction focus. President Trump maintained the office with an emphasis on religious liberty issues. The Biden executive order returns the office to an economic and community development orientation.

Legal Framework:

The executive order operates within the bounds of existing constitutional law on separation of church and state. Federal funding for faith-based organizations' service activities is permitted so long as those activities are not explicitly religious in nature. The order calls for a review of agency partnerships with faith-based organizations to ensure compliance with constitutional and statutory requirements.

Higher Education Context:

Many higher education institutions, both public and private, have long histories of collaboration with faith-based organizations in areas such as community service, experiential learning, and research. These partnerships have grown more sophisticated over time, with some universities establishing dedicated interfaith or community engagement centers. At the same time, universities must navigate complex issues around academic freedom, institutional autonomy, and church-state separation when aligning activities with faith-based groups or government objectives.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Executive order 14008 makes addressing climate change a top priority for U.S. foreign policy, national security, and the entire federal government.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order Mobilizes Federal Government to Address Climate Crisis, Signaling Sweeping Changes

Overview: Executive Order 14008, titled 'Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad', makes addressing climate change an urgent priority across the federal government. It frames the issue as central to U.S. foreign policy and national security, directing agencies to integrate climate considerations into international engagement, analysis, and decision-making. Domestically, it kickstarts an all-of-government approach to reduce emissions and build resilience.

Bottom Line: The order signals transformational policy changes to confront the climate crisis that will have significant ripple effects across higher education, from research priorities to campus operations. Institutions that proactively align with these priorities will be well-positioned to benefit from federal resources and partnership opportunities.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

The order builds on a series of Obama-era executive actions on climate change, while signaling a more aggressive approach commensurate with the urgency of the crisis. It revokes a number of Trump administration orders that rolled back climate protections.

Legal Framework:

The order leverages authorities under the Clean Air Act, Energy Policy Act, and Energy Independence and Security Act, among others. Agencies will undertake new rule-makings to achieve the goals outlined.

Higher Education Context:

The higher education sector is already a leader in climate change research and sustainability, but the order accelerates the shift to a clean energy economy. Universities will need to balance energy transition in their own operations with evolving workforce demands.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research: The order's emphasis on climate science, clean energy innovation, and technology transfer could drive a significant shift in federal research priorities and funding. Universities with strong climate and sustainability research programs may see increased opportunities. However, institutions heavily invested in fossil fuel-dependent research could face challenges.

Education: As the career landscape evolves to meet the needs of a clean energy economy, student interest in climate-related education is likely to increase. Universities have an opportunity to expand academic offerings in fields like environmental science, sustainable engineering and clean energy. Climate change will also need to be integrated across disciplines.

Public Engagement: The order directs agencies to increase climate change outreach to communities and stakeholders. Higher education institutions are uniquely positioned to support this effort through public education, community partnerships, and thought leadership.

Operations: With the federal government leading by example to achieve a carbon pollution-free electricity sector by 2035 and net-zero emissions by 2050, universities will face increased pressure from stakeholders to accelerate sustainability efforts. This may include transitioning to renewable energy, reducing waste, improving efficiency of campus facilities, and addressing sustainability in supply chains.

Global Engagement: As climate change is further integrated into foreign policy and international development efforts, universities involved in global research partnerships and education programs may see a shift in priorities and funding. Institutions will be key partners in providing international climate change education and fostering global cooperation.

Important Dates:

  • 02/29/2021: White House climate task force to provide progress report
  • Ongoing: Agencies to release climate adaptation and resilience plans
  • COP26 (11/2021): U.S. to announce updated emissions target

Affected Departments:

President/Chancellor's Office, Provost and Academic Affairs, Research Administration, Government Relations, Facilities and Operations, Student Affairs, Budget and Finance, Communications

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

While the order does not introduce new compliance requirements for universities, institutions will need to adapt to changes in federal grant conditions, reporting requirements, and agency rule-makings and policies across all areas implicated (e.g. research, financial aid, facilities, etc.)

Technical Analysis:

Effective implementation will require assessment of technical needs related to research infrastructure (e.g. lab facilities for new energy technologies), national security research (e.g. climate modeling), and campus sustainability (e.g. micro-grid electricity systems, carbon emissions tracking systems.)

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Notably, the order's direction to integrate climate into national security considerations could affect defense-related research. The Justice40 initiative's goal to deliver 40% of clean energy investment benefits to disadvantaged communities implicates how universities partner with local communities.

Risk Analysis:

Failure to adapt to new federal priorities could result in competitive disadvantages in securing grants, contracts and other funding. Reputational risk among environmentally-conscious students and faculty. Potential legal/regulatory risk of non-compliance with new agency rules.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Universities that are able to quickly mobilize research and education capabilities to support federal climate priorities will have a significant competitive advantage. Institutions may need to assess their positioning and differentiation in climate-related education and workforce development.

Long-term Vision:

The order represents a paradigm shift where addressing climate change becomes a central organizing principle of federal policy-making. Higher education's research, education and thought leadership functions will be integral to achieving the order's vision of a sustainable, equitable clean energy future.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities, individually and through associations, should actively engage with the White House, federal agencies and Congress to help shape implementation. Key issues include research funding priorities, technology transfer policies, and education/workforce programs.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes. The far-reaching nature of this executive order demands a coordinated, strategic response from higher education institutions. Universities must review the details of the order, analyze implications across different mission areas, and develop a comprehensive plan to align research, education, and operations with federal climate priorities. Effective response will require engagement at all levels, from university leadership to individual faculty, students, and staff.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Establish cross-functional climate response task force
  • Map current research, education and operations to identify alignment
  • Analyze federal funding landscape and identify opportunities
  • Communicate importance to university community and stakeholders

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Develop institution-wide climate action plan
  • Identify and pursue priority funding opportunities
  • Incorporate climate considerations into all new initiatives
  • Launch faculty/student ideation on research and curriculum

Long-term Considerations:

  • Ensure climate is central to university strategic planning
  • Invest in faculty hiring and program development in key areas
  • Collaborate with other institutions and partners on major initiatives
  • Continuously monitor and adapt to evolving federal priorities

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Potential need for new sustainability staff, grant managers, government relations. May require faculty hiring in climate/clean energy disciplines.

Budget: Assess current allocation to climate efforts, identify opportunities to secure and redirect resources. Budget for energy efficiency upgrades.

Technology: Research computing needs for modeling/analysis. Sustainability/carbon tracking tools. Clean energy infrastructure.

External Expertise: Engage with climate policy, clean energy, and sustainability experts to inform strategy. Partner with climate organizations.

Executive Brief

Prohibits U.S. investment in publicly traded securities of companies identified as supporting China's military. Universities should review endowment holdings for exposure.
comprehensive_analysis:
Restricting U.S. Investment in Chinese Military Companies

Overview: Prohibits all U.S. persons from purchasing or holding publicly traded securities (or derivatives) of companies identified as "Communist Chinese military companies." Requires divestment of existing positions within 365 days. Expansive definition of covered companies supporting China's military-industrial complex.

Bottom Line: Universities must thoroughly review endowment exposures, divest prohibited holdings by November 11, 2021, and consider broader implications for research and global engagement with China.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

Reflects escalating U.S.-China tensions and concerns over China's military-civil fusion. Builds on prior restrictions on telecom giant Huawei and others. First formal investment ban.

Legal Framework:

Relies on International Emergency Economic Powers Act and National Emergencies Act. Definition of "Communist Chinese military company" derives from Section 1237 of National Defense Authorization Act.

Higher Education Context:

Growing focus on Chinese influence at U.S. universities. Congress pushing for stricter controls on China-related funding and research. Bipartisan support likely to sustain these measures.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Endowment Management: Requires immediate review of all holdings for exposure to designated entities and divestment of prohibited securities. May necessitate changes to investment strategies and manager selections.

Research Funding: Potential impact on research grants, contracts and gifts from entities with suspected links to sanctioned companies. Requires enhanced screening of Chinese sponsors.

International Programs: May jeopardize academic partnerships and exchange programs with Chinese universities involved in defense research. Demands caution around military-adjacent collaborations.

Overseas Operations: Could restrict financial transactions and operations in China more broadly. May require wind-down of certain in-country activities.

Reputation/Perception: Association with sanctioned entities, even if divested, could draw public criticism. Communications strategy needed.

Important Dates:

  • 11/12/2020: Prohibitions on new purchases take effect
  • 01/11/2021: 365-day divestment period begins
  • 11/11/2021: Divestment must be completed with reports filed

Affected Departments:

Investment Office, Research Administration, Global Engagement, Federal Relations, Public Affairs, Legal Counsel

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

Detailed transaction reports must be submitted to OFAC within 30 days of divestment. Documentation of decision-making and reasonable due diligence will be critical.

Technical Analysis:

Precise ownership threshold for prohibited securities still unclear. Sanctions could extend to subsidiaries even without direct listings. Indexes and derivatives add complexity.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Restricting Chinese access to U.S. university endowments, research and campuses represents a sea change. Major shift in posture will affect student recruitment, faculty exchanges and overseas presence.

Risk Analysis:

Aggressive and expansive implementation by the government could rapidly designate new entities with little warning. Diligence into counterparty identities and source of funds will be essential.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions with greater exposure to China financially and programmatically face higher risk and compliance burdens. Deft management of Chinese relationships will be a key differentiator.

Long-term Vision:

U.S.-China decoupling likely to accelerate with further restrictions. Education may be on the frontlines of bilateral frictions. Scenario planning around research security and market access should guide strategies.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher education associations should collectively engage OFAC, SEC, DOD and others around workable implementation. Clarification of scope and allowances for academic activity is needed.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - Universities as U.S. persons are clearly subject to the prohibitions and must fully comply. Penalties for violations include civil fines up to $250,000 and criminal prosecution.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review and map all holdings for exposures to designated entities
  • Notify external managers not to make new investments
  • Develop comprehensive divestment plan and timeline
  • Establish criteria for identifying problematic Chinese sponsors

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Complete required divestments prior to deadline
  • Update investment policy statements
  • Expand research compliance screenings
  • Review academic partnerships with China

Long-term Considerations:

  • Continue monitoring for additional sanctioned entities
  • Assess overall risk exposure to China across functions
  • Engage with policymakers on impact to higher education

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Dedicated compliance team with counter-party screening capabilities

Budget: Meaningful financial and administrative costs of divestment and ongoing monitoring

Technology: Securities screening and supply chain mapping software may be required

External Expertise: Outside counsel and risk advisory services versed in sanctions regimes

Executive Brief

President Trump imposed new economic sanctions on Iran's construction, mining, manufacturing, and textiles sectors. The direct impact on U.S. higher education appears limited.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order 13902: Expansion of Iran Sanctions Likely Has Limited Higher Education Impact

Overview: On January 10, 2020, President Trump signed Executive Order 13902, imposing new sanctions on the construction, mining, manufacturing, and textiles sectors of Iran's economy. This action builds upon the administration's 'maximum pressure' campaign aimed at compelling changes in Iran's behavior by applying economic pressure.

Bottom Line: The new sanctions on additional sectors of Iran's economy do not appear to significantly impact the operations of most U.S. colleges and universities. However, institutions with investments, partnerships, or programs relating to the newly sanctioned sectors should carefully evaluate their exposure.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

The U.S. has imposed increasingly stringent sanctions on Iran since the Trump administration withdrew from the Iran nuclear deal in 2018. These sanctions aim to pressure Iran by limiting its economic activity and reducing its oil exports. Higher education has not been a primary focus of recent sanctions.

Legal Framework:

The President issued the sanctions under the authority of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), the National Emergencies Act (NEA), and other statutes. The Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) administers and enforces the sanctions.

Higher Education Context:

U.S. colleges and universities must ensure compliance with Iran sanctions, like other regulated sectors. Schools with investments, partnerships, or other ties to the newly sanctioned sectors face the most significant potential impact.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Investments: University endowments and employee retirement plans must ensure any holdings related to the sanctioned sectors of Iran's economy are compliant with the updated sanctions. However, given existing sanctions, most institutions likely have little to no direct exposure.

Research Partnerships: Universities should re-evaluate any research partnerships with Iranian entities to determine if they intersect with newly sanctioned sectors. If so, those ties may need to be terminated or restructured to ensure compliance.

Educational Exchanges: Academic exchanges and study abroad programs focused on Iran should be reviewed to avoid activities related to sanctioned sectors. In most cases, the new sanctions are unlikely to significantly affect overall educational exchanges with Iran, which are already limited.

International Students: The new sanctions do not directly affect Iranian students in the U.S. However, some students may face increased scrutiny around ties to sanctioned sectors. Universities can support affected students while ensuring their own compliance.

Regulatory Compliance: Higher education institutions must navigate a complex array of U.S. sanctions and export control regulations. The new sanctions add to this complexity but do not fundamentally change most universities' existing compliance obligations and processes.

Important Dates:

  • 01/10/2020: Executive Order 13902 signed by President Trump
  • 01/10/2020: New sanctions on construction, mining, manufacturing, and textiles sectors of Iran's economy take effect

Affected Departments:

Financial Administration and Investment Office, Office of General Counsel, International Affairs and Global Partnerships, Research Administration and Sponsored Programs, Study Abroad Office

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

The Executive Order prohibits U.S. persons from engaging in transactions with the sanctioned sectors of Iran's economy. Universities should consult with legal counsel to determine how their activities may be affected based on a risk-based compliance assessment.

Technical Analysis:

The sanctions target Iran's construction, mining, manufacturing, and textiles sectors, which are already significantly affected by existing U.S. sanctions. The new sanctions also authorize secondary sanctions on foreign financial institutions that conduct certain transactions with the targeted sectors.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

While the sanctions primarily implicate financial and international affairs units, they also affect research administration, study abroad, and student services. Effective compliance requires coordination across these areas.

Risk Analysis:

The primary compliance risks relate to investments, financial transactions, and partnerships that may involve the sanctioned sectors. Violations could result in significant penalties. However, most institutions' exposure is likely low if they were already complying with previous sanctions.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions with more extensive global partnerships, particularly those with ties to Iran, may face greater compliance burdens and potential competitive impacts compared to schools with more limited international engagement.

Long-term Vision:

The new sanctions are part of an evolving landscape of U.S. economic restrictions affecting higher education. Schools must be agile in adapting to these changes while still advancing their educational missions and global engagement strategies.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher education associations may engage with policymakers to ensure sanctions do not unduly restrict educational activities. Schools can provide input on the impacts of sanctions policies to inform future implementation.

Action Plan:

Action Required: No, for most institutions, unless significant ties to the sanctioned Iranian sectors exist, in which case those relationships need to be evaluated and modified as needed to ensure compliance.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Brief relevant offices on the new sanctions and potential implications.
  • Review investments for any exposure to newly sanctioned sectors.
  • Identify university partnerships potentially affected by the sanctions.
  • Evaluate whether study abroad programs have ties to sanctioned sectors.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Divest any noncompliant holdings and amend investment policies if needed.
  • Terminate or restructure partnerships that could violate sanctions.
  • Modify study abroad programs to avoid activities with sanctioned sectors.
  • Support international students while ensuring institutional compliance.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Monitor further developments in U.S. sanctions against Iran that could affect higher education activities.
  • Foster ongoing dialogue between financial administration, international offices, and compliance units to manage sanction risks.
  • Consider how sanctions affect the institution's overall global engagement strategy.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Most institutions will not require additional personnel, unless significant compliance issues are identified.

Budget: Costs may include divesting assets, terminating contracts, and obtaining legal advice. However, the overall budgetary impact for many schools will be minimal.

Technology: Existing sanctions compliance and risk management systems should be sufficient for most institutions.

External Expertise: Schools may need to consult with outside counsel, particularly if they have significant ties to Iran that need to be restructured.

executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Reimposed economic sanctions on Iran may impact university research, faculty, and students. Review implications.
comprehensive_analysis:
U.S. Reinstates Extensive Economic Sanctions Against Iran

Overview: Following the U.S. withdrawal from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) in May 2018, this executive order comprehensively reinstated the U.S. sanctions regime against Iran that had been waived or lifted under the JCPOA. The sanctions target Iran's energy, shipping, shipbuilding, financial, insurance, and other sectors and penalize foreign companies and financial institutions that do business with Iran.

Bottom Line: Universities must carefully navigate the complexities of the reinstated sanctions regime to ensure compliance and mitigate potential negative impacts on research activities, faculty, and students.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

The JCPOA, agreed to in 2015 between Iran and the P5+1 nations, had lifted many of the sanctions on Iran in exchange for restrictions on Iran's nuclear program. The U.S. withdrawal from the deal and the snapback of sanctions represents a major shift in U.S. policy toward Iran.

Legal Framework:

The reinstated sanctions draw upon a range of legal authorities, including the Iran Sanctions Act, the Iran Threat Reduction and Syria Human Rights Act, and the Iran Freedom and Counter-Proliferation Act. The order delegates some implementation authorities to the Departments of State and Treasury.

Higher Education Context:

The reinstatement of sanctions significantly raises the legal and financial risks for higher education institutions collaborating with Iranian entities. It also contributes to a more challenging environment for international research and student mobility.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Activities: The sanctions may restrict certain research collaborations with Iranian entities, limit funding from Iranian sources, and complicate the exchange of research materials and equipment.

Faculty Mobility: Travel to Iran for conferences, field work, or other academic activities may be restricted. Visa difficulties could prevent Iranian faculty from coming to the U.S.

Student Enrollments: Iranian students may face challenges obtaining visas, paying tuition, and accessing financial aid due to the sanctions. This could lead to a decline in Iranian student enrollments.

Funding Sources: Funding from Iranian government entities, companies, or individuals may no longer be feasible. Universities may need to end certain grant programs and find alternative funding.

Overseas Operations: University programs or campuses in Iran may need to be restructured or closed due to financial restrictions and legal risks under the sanctions.

Important Dates:

  • 08/07/2018: First set of sanctions reimposed after 90-day wind-down period
  • 11/05/2018: Remaining sanctions, including on Iran's oil and financial sectors, resume after 180-day wind-down

Affected Departments:

Research Administration and Compliance, International Programs/Global Affairs, Student Financial Aid and Visa Services, Grants and Contracts, Legal Counsel

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

The order requires U.S. persons to comply with the sanctions and imposes strict liability civil penalties for violations. It also mandates the Department of Treasury to implement compliance reporting requirements.

Technical Analysis:

Specific sanctions target Iran's currency, auto, precious metal, and industrial trade. General licenses provide some limited exemptions for humanitarian, journalistic, and agricultural products.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

The sanctions intersect with export control regulations, visa and immigration policies, and research integrity standards. Implementation requires coordination across multiple administrative functions.

Risk Analysis:

Violations, even if inadvertent, carry significant financial and reputational risks. Proactive compliance efforts and a risk-based approach are essential.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Institutions with more extensive ties to Iran face greater compliance burdens and costs. However, those that adapt quickly may gain advantages in pivoting to new markets.

Long-term Vision:

The sanctions align with a broader trend of greater oversight of U.S. universities' global activities. Institutions must balance international engagement with compliance in an evolving geopolitical landscape.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Higher education associations may advocate for general licenses allowing educational exchanges. Individual institutions can comment on proposed implementation rules.

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - The wide-ranging sanctions necessitate a thorough review of university activities involving Iran and updates to institutional policies and procedures to ensure compliance.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Establish a task force to assess the institution's touchpoints with Iran and potential sanctions exposure.
  • Suspend any transactions with Iranian entities until a full compliance review can be completed.
  • Communicate the sanctions to relevant faculty, staff, and students and provide initial guidance.
  • Engage outside legal expertise for assistance interpreting and applying the complex sanctions.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Conduct a comprehensive audit of research projects, contracts, and partnerships for potential Iran links.
  • Develop and implement updated compliance policies and procedures aligned with the sanctions.
  • Provide detailed guidance and training to affected university stakeholders.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Continually monitor sanctions developments and evolving U.S.-Iran relations.
  • Assess shifts in global research funding and collaboration toward other regions.
  • Consider advocating, potentially with other institutions, for reasonable educational exemptions.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Additional staff in compliance, international affairs, and sponsored projects may be required to manage the increased workload.

Budget: The costs of compliance, legal guidance, and reduced funding could require budget reallocations.

Technology: Enhanced restricted party screening and export compliance software may be necessary.

External Expertise: The complexity of the sanctions may necessitate engaging specialized outside counsel and consultants.
